Get started

Luke A McGuinness

2020-04-17

Source: vignettes/medrxivr.Rmd
medrxivr.Rmd

Perform a simple search

library(medrxivr)

results <- mx_search("dementia")

Dataset description

The dataset (in this case, results) returned by the search function above contains 10 variables:

Variable Description
ID Unique identifier
title Preprint title
abstract Preprint abstract
first_author Last name of the first author of the preprint. There are plans to update this field to contain all authors names
date_posted Date the preprint was posted, in the format YYYYMMDD
subject medRxiv classifies each preprint into one of a set number of subject categories. Not this is not always available for recent preprints.
doi Preprint Digital Object Identifier
link_page Link to preprint webpage. Note, this only specifes the file path from the base medRxiv url (https://www.medrxiv.org), e.g “/content/10.1101/19012377v1?versioned=TRUE”. The “?versioned=TRUE” is required, as otherwise, the URL will resolve to the most recent version of the article (assuming there is >1 version available).
link_pdf Link to preprint PDF. This is used by mx_download() to download a copy of the PDF for that preprint.
link_bibtex Link to preprint bibtex file

Download PDFs for records identified by your search

Pass the results of your search above (results) to the mx_download() function to download a copy of the PDF for each record. Note: downloaded PDFs are named using the value of the ID column in the dataset, which serves as a unique identifier for each record.

mx_download(results,        # Object returned by mx_search
            "pdf/",         # Directory to save PDFs to 
            create = TRUE)  # Create the directory if it doesn't exist

Further guidance

Please see the Building complex search strategies vignette for extended guidance on developing search strategies for use with medrxivr.
